journal-title-group.journal-title: SAE International Journal of Transportation Safety

title-group.article-title: Cellular Helmet Liner Design through Bio-inspired Structures and Topology Optimization of Compliant Mechanism Lattices

abstract.p: The continuous development of sport technologies constantly demands advancements in protective headgear to reduce the risk of head injuries. This article introduces new cellular helmet liner designs through two approaches. The first approach is the study of energy-absorbing biological materials. The second approach is the study of lattices comprised of force-diverting compliant mechanisms. On the one hand, bio-inspired liners are generated through the study of biological, hierarchical materials. An emphasis is given on structures in nature that serve similar concussion-reducing functions as a helmet liner. Inspiration is drawn from organic and skeletal structures. On the other hand, compliant mechanism lattice (CML)-based liners use topology optimization to synthesize rubber cellular unit cells with effective positive and negative Poisson’s ratios. Three lattices are designed using different cellular unit cell arrangements, namely, all positive, all negative, and alternating effective Poisson’s ratios. The proposed cellular (bio-inspired and CML-based) liners are embedded between two polycarbonate shells, thereby, replacing the traditional expanded polypropylene foam liner used in standard sport helmets. The cellular liners are analyzed through a series of 2D extruded ballistic impact simulations to determine the best performing liner topology and its corresponding rubber hardness. The cellular design with the best performance is compared against an expanded polypropylene foam liner in a 3D simulation to appraise its protection capabilities and verify that the 2D extruded design simulations scale to an effective 3D design.

caption.p: Bio-inspired designs: (a) pumpkin, (b) stacked diatom skeletal, (c) internal Fibonacci spiral, (d) haystack, (e) wheel spoke, (f) external Fibonacci spiral, (g) spiral wave, (h) double helix, (i) hexagonal spring. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Flowchart of the bio-inspired design process. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis

Example of a bio-inspired design: biological form of a diatom skeletal remains under an electron microscope (left) and the corresponding engineering form (right) reproduced in Zbrush. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis

Section of 1 × 3 cellular unit cells of the peel design (bottom) inspired by the dense and porous layers (exocarp and mesocarp) of a pomelo peel (top) [54]. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Section of 1 × 3 cellular unit cells of the shell design (bottom) inspired by the cross-sectional topology of a nautilus shell (top). © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis

Section of 1 × 3 cellular unit cells of the bone design (bottom) inspired by the sandwich of (a) compact and (b) spongy bone found in a woodpecker’s skull (top) [37]. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis

Optimized topologies of the positive mechanism (left) and the negative mechanism (right) with corresponding section views of loads and boundary conditions of a quarter design domain. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Three-dimensional optimized topologies of positive (top) and negative (bottom) mechanisms. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Simulation of NOCSAE Drop Test Method ND 001 on a basic foam-based helmet to determine width of (top side) impact area. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Bio-inspired liner assemblies: peel liner (top), shell liner (middle), and bone liner (bottom). © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
CML-based liner assemblies: positive liner PL (top), negative liner NL (middle), and zero liner ZL (bottom). © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
2D ballistic simulation setup for the positive liner (PL) design. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Pairwise comparison table for weight calculation. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis

Deformation at peak displacement of the inner shell for (a) peel liner (dmax = 1.6 mm), (b) shell liner (dmax = 2.8 mm), (c) bone liner (dmax = 1.9 mm), (d) positive liner PL (dmax = 1.9 mm), (e) negative liner NL (dmax = 1.4 mm), and (f) zero liner ZL (dmax = 2.8 mm) (MEP test pad hidden for clarity). © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Displacement-acceleration and time-acceleration profiles of the six (basic) liners using Shore 60A rubber. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
PIE as a function of the horizontal position of the unit cells for the bio-inspired and CML-based (basic) liners using Shore 60A rubber. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Performance [normalized] values for the analysis of basic liners. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Displacement-acceleration and time-acceleration profiles for the parametric study of the peel (40A-70A), PL (50A-80A), and foam liners. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
PIE as a function of the horizontal position of the unit cells for the parametric study of the peel, PL, and foam liners. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Performance [normalized] values for the parametric study of rubber hardness. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
3D ballistic simulation setup for the PL design. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Deformation of the 3D PL with 70A rubber at peak displacement of the impactor. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Performance values of the 2D and 3D liners. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis

Displacement-acceleration and time-acceleration profiles for the EPP foam liner and CML-based PL design with 70A rubber: comparison of 2D and 3D models. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Polycarbonate shell material keycard. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
Impactor material keycard. © Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis
